text:
Example: Money-weighted rate of return
Assume an investor buys a share of stock for $100 at t = 0 and at the end of the year (t
= 1), she buys an additional share for $120. At the end of Year 2, the investor sells both
shares for $130 each. At the end of each year in the holding period, the stock paid a
$2.00 per share dividend. What is the money-weighted rate of return?
Step 1: Determine the timing of each cash flow and whether the cash flow is an inflow
(+), into the account, or an outflow (-), available from the account.
